clusters.title: Pakistan in 'open war' with Afghanistan, Pakistani defence minister says
clusters.neutral_headline: Pakistan bombs Kabul after intensifying border clashes with Afghanistan
bullet_summary: Pakistan's defence minister has said that the ​country ‌is in an "open ​war" with neighbouring Afghanistan, after both nations launched airstrikes overnight
Following months of tit-for-tat clashes, Afghan forces attacked Pakistani border troops on Thursday night in what the Taliban government said was retaliation for earlier deadly air strikes
The Afghan Taliban said it had responded to the Pakistani strikes, which targeted Afghan cities including Kabul and Kandahar
Pakistan bombed major Afghan cities, including Kabul, on Friday, as Defence Minister Khawaja Asif said the countries were in “open war” after months of escalating clashes

items.title: Pakistan in 'open war' with Afghanistan, Pakistani defence minister says
items.standfirst: Pakistan's defence minister has said that the ​country ‌is in an "open ​war" with neighbouring Afghanistan, after both nations launched airstrikes overnight.
items.content: Pakistan's defence minister has said that the ​country ‌is in an "open ​war" with neighbouring Afghanistan, after both nations launched airstrikes overnight.

items.title: Pakistan bombs Kabul after intensifying border clashes with Afghanistan
items.standfirst: Escalation of violence between the volatile neighbours makes a Qatar-mediated ceasefire appear increasingly shakyPakistan bombed Afghanistan’s capital of Kabul and two other provinces on Friday, hours after a cross-border attack, the latest escalation of violence between the volatile neighbours who signed a Qatar-mediated ceasefire in 2025.Following months of tit-for-tat clashes, Afghan forces attacked Pakistani border troops on Thursday night in what the Taliban government said was retaliation for earlier deadly air strikes. Continue reading...
items.content: Escalation of violence between the volatile neighbours makes a Qatar-mediated ceasefire appear increasingly shakyPakistan bombed Afghanistan’s capital of Kabul and two other provinces on Friday, hours after a cross-border attack, the latest escalation of violence between the volatile neighbours who signed a Qatar-mediated ceasefire in 2025.Following months of tit-for-tat clashes, Afghan forces attacked Pakistani border troops on Thursday night in what the Taliban government said was retaliation for earlier deadly air strikes. Continue reading...

items.title: LIVE: Pakistan declares ‘open war’ on Afghanistan, fighter jets bomb Kabul
items.standfirst: Pakistani and Afghan officials have both declared full military operations as border clashes intensify.
items.content: Pakistani and Afghan officials have both declared full military operations as border clashes intensify.

items.title: Airstrikes hit Afghan capital of Kabul, hours after Afghanistan attacks Pakistan
items.standfirst: Pakistan carried out airstrikes hours after Afghanistan launched a cross-border attack in the latest escalation of violence between the neighboring countries. The clashes are making a Qatar-mediated ceasefire appear increasingly shaky.
items.content: Pakistan carried out airstrikes hours after Afghanistan launched a cross-border attack in the latest escalation of violence between the neighboring countries. The clashes are making a Qatar-mediated ceasefire appear increasingly shaky.(Image credit: AP)

items.title: Pakistan strikes Afghan cities as cross-border attacks escalate
items.standfirst: The Afghan Taliban said it had responded to the Pakistani strikes, which targeted Afghan cities including Kabul and Kandahar.
items.content: The Afghan Taliban said it had responded to the Pakistani strikes, which targeted Afghan cities including Kabul and Kandahar.

items.title: Pakistan bombs Kabul, declares ‘open war’ with Afghanistan after months of border clashes
items.standfirst: Pakistan bombed major Afghan cities, including Kabul, on Friday, as Defence Minister Khawaja Asif said the countries were in “open war” after months of escalating clashes. Afghan forces earlier attacked Pakistani border posts in retaliation for air strikes, while residents in Kabul and Kandahar reported explosions and jets overhead.
items.content: Pakistan bombed major Afghan cities, including Kabul, on Friday, as Defence Minister Khawaja Asif said the countries were in “open war” after months of escalating clashes. Afghan forces earlier attacked Pakistani border posts in retaliation for air strikes, while residents in Kabul and Kandahar reported explosions and jets overhead.

items.title: Anthropic Rejects Latest Pentagon Offer, Escalating AI Feud
items.standfirst: Anthropic PBC rejected the Pentagon’s latest offer in a dispute over safeguards around the use of its artificial intelligence technology by the US military, escalating the standoff a day before a government deadline for the company to drop its restrictions or face severe consequences.
items.content: Anthropic PBC rejected the Pentagon’s latest offer in a dispute over safeguards around the use of its artificial intelligence technology by the US military, escalating the standoff a day before a government deadline for the company to drop its restrictions or face severe consequences.

items.title: Anthropic CEO says AI company 'cannot in good conscience accede' to Pentagon's demands
items.standfirst: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei says AI company 'cannot in good conscience accede' to Pentagon's demands to allow wider use of its tech. Defense officials in the Trump administration warned they could designate Anthropic, which makes the AI chatbot Claude, as a supply chain risk — or invoke a Cold War-era law called the Defense Production Act to give the military more sweeping authority to use its products, even if the company doesn’t approve. FRANCE 24's Wassim Cornet reports from Los Angeles.
items.content: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei says AI company 'cannot in good conscience accede' to Pentagon's demands to allow wider use of its tech. Defense officials in the Trump administration warned they could designate Anthropic, which makes the AI chatbot Claude, as a supply chain risk — or invoke a Cold War-era law called the Defense Production Act to give the military more sweeping authority to use its products, even if the company doesn’t approve. FRANCE 24's Wassim Cornet reports from Los Angeles.

The Pentagon has asked Anthropic to lift limits the company places on how its Claude model can be used by the military.…

items.title: Hillary Clinton calls for Trump to testify at US House Epstein hearing

items.content: The former secretary of state accused the Republican-led panel of seeking to protect political allies in probe.

items.title: Hillary Clinton calls for Trump to testify as she faces US House Epstein panel
items.standfirst: Hillary Clinton used her forced appearance Thursday before a Republican-led panel probing Jeffrey Epstein to go on the offensive by demanding President Donald Trump testify about his own links to the sex offender. Clinton told the congressional committee she had no information about Epstein's crimes, never recalled encountering him, and had never visited his island or flown on his plane, accusing the panel of trying to "protect one public official" -- Trump.
items.content: Hillary Clinton used her forced appearance Thursday before a Republican-led panel probing Jeffrey Epstein to go on the offensive by demanding President Donald Trump testify about his own links to the sex offender. Clinton told the congressional committee she had no information about Epstein's crimes, never recalled encountering him, and had never visited his island or flown on his plane, accusing the panel of trying to "protect one public official" -- Trump.

items.title: Hillary Clinton testifies in Epstein files probe
items.standfirst: The Republican head of the US Ovesight Committee making the journey with the rest of his panel from Washington to the sleepy Hudson Valley suburb of Chappaqua, New York, home of former US president Bill Clinton who will testify Friday over relations with Jeffrey Epstein. First, his wife - former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton - who's behind closed doors with the lawmakers as we speak. Democratic political consultant Christian Hanley joins us from Washington.
items.content: The Republican head of the US Ovesight Committee making the journey with the rest of his panel from Washington to the sleepy Hudson Valley suburb of Chappaqua, New York, home of former US president Bill Clinton who will testify Friday over relations with Jeffrey Epstein. First, his wife - former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton - who's behind closed doors with the lawmakers as we speak. Democratic political consultant Christian Hanley joins us from Washington.

items.title: Paramount clinches Warner Bros deal after Netflix walks away
items.standfirst: Streaming company’s decision ends months-long battle to buy parent of CNN, HBO and franchises like Harry Potter
items.content: Streaming company’s decision ends months-long battle to buy parent of CNN, HBO and franchises like Harry Potter

items.title: Netflix Drops Out of Fight to Buy Warner Bros.
items.standfirst: Netflix has decided not to increase its bid for Warner Brothers Discovery, citing that the deal is no longer financially attractive despite previously considering it value-creating. This announcement follows Paramount's offer being declared the superior deal by Warner Bros. Seven Letter Partner Annalyse Keller, Democratic Strategist Arshi Siddiqui and Bloomberg's Kailey Leinz discuss on "Balance of Power: Evening Edition." (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Netflix has decided not to increase its bid for Warner Brothers Discovery, citing that the deal is no longer financially attractive despite previously considering it value-creating. This announcement follows Paramount's offer being declared the superior deal by Warner Bros. Seven Letter Partner Annalyse Keller, Democratic Strategist Arshi Siddiqui and Bloomberg's Kailey Leinz discuss on "Balance of Power: Evening Edition." (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: Warner Bros. Says Paramount Offer Is Superior to Netflix Proposal
items.standfirst: Warner Brothers Discovery's board has officially recognized Paramount's acquisition proposal as a superior offer compared to Netflix's earlier deal. Lucas Shaw reports on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Warner Brothers Discovery's board has officially recognized Paramount's acquisition proposal as a superior offer compared to Netflix's earlier deal. Lucas Shaw reports on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

clusters.title: Breaking down what U.S. and Iran want out of nuclear talks
clusters.neutral_headline: US-Iran talks end after 'significant progress', mediator says
bullet_summary: The Iranian foreign minister said the two sides made good progress and will meet for another round next week
Reported by CBS News, Reuters Top News, BBC World and others

items.title: Breaking down what U.S. and Iran want out of nuclear talks
items.standfirst: The U.S. and Iran held a third round of indirect nuclear talks in Geneva on Thursday. The Iranian foreign minister said the two sides made good progress and will meet for another round next week. Alan Eyre, a distinguished diplomatic fellow at the Middle East Institute, joins "The Daily Report" to discuss.
items.content: The U.S. and Iran held a third round of indirect nuclear talks in Geneva on Thursday. The Iranian foreign minister said the two sides made good progress and will meet for another round next week. Alan Eyre, a distinguished diplomatic fellow at the Middle East Institute, joins "The Daily Report" to discuss.

items.title: US and Iran hold a third round of indirect talks in Geneva
items.standfirst: Iran and the United States were holding another round of indirect talks in Geneva on Thursday (February 26) to try to reach a deal on Tehran's nuclear program and potentially avert another war as the United States gathers a massive fleet of aircraft and warships in the Middle East.
items.content: Iran and the United States were holding another round of indirect talks in Geneva on Thursday (February 26) to try to reach a deal on Tehran's nuclear program and potentially avert another war as the United States gathers a massive fleet of aircraft and warships in the Middle East.

clusters.title: Columbia student released after being detained by DHS agents
clusters.neutral_headline: Columbia University says US immigration agents lied to detain student
bullet_summary: The Department of Homeland Security said ICE agents detained Elmina "Ellie" Aghayeva at Columbia University Thursday, saying her student visa was revoked in 2016
Reported by CBS News, Al Jazeera, NPR News and others

items.title: Columbia student released after being detained by DHS agents
items.standfirst: The Department of Homeland Security said ICE agents detained Elmina "Ellie" Aghayeva at Columbia University Thursday, saying her student visa was revoked in 2016. She was later released.
items.content: The Department of Homeland Security said ICE agents detained Elmina "Ellie" Aghayeva at Columbia University Thursday, saying her student visa was revoked in 2016. She was later released.

items.title: Columbia student released from DHS custody after Mamdani shared concerns with Trump
items.standfirst: A Columbia University student was detained by federal agents Thursday morning at one of its residential buildings and was later released after New York Mayor Zohran Mamdani brought up the case in a meeting with President Trump. Tom Hanson has more.
items.content: A Columbia University student was detained by federal agents Thursday morning at one of its residential buildings and was later released after New York Mayor Zohran Mamdani brought up the case in a meeting with President Trump. Tom Hanson has more.

items.title: What we know about Columbia student's arrest, release by federal agents
items.standfirst: Protests broke out on Thursday in Manhattan after immigration agents arrested a student at Columbia University inside a residential building owned by the school. She was released a few hours later. CBS News immigration correspondent Camilo Montoya-Galvez has more.
items.content: Protests broke out on Thursday in Manhattan after immigration agents arrested a student at Columbia University inside a residential building owned by the school. She was released a few hours later. CBS News immigration correspondent Camilo Montoya-Galvez has more.

items.title: Cuba vows to fight ‘terrorist aggression’ after attack from US-registered boat
items.standfirst: Cuban president says country will ‘defend itself with determination’ after deadly coastal assault by exilesWhat we know so far about the deadly boat shooting off Cuba’s coastCuba has vowed to defend itself against any “terrorist and mercenary aggression”, a day after border guards said they had killed four exiles on a Florida-registered speedboat that opened fire on a patrol.Cuba’s president, Miguel Díaz-Canel, wrote on X that the Caribbean country would “defend itself with determination and firmness” after the incident in which six other people on the boat were injured. Continue reading...
items.content: Cuban president says country will ‘defend itself with determination’ after deadly coastal assault by exilesWhat we know so far about the deadly boat shooting off Cuba’s coastCuba has vowed to defend itself against any “terrorist and mercenary aggression”, a day after border guards said they had killed four exiles on a Florida-registered speedboat that opened fire on a patrol.Cuba’s president, Miguel Díaz-Canel, wrote on X that the Caribbean country would “defend itself with determination and firmness” after the incident in which six other people on the boat were injured. items.title: Cuba says it killed heavily armed exiles who attacked from US-registered speedboat
items.standfirst: Rare clash off island’s coast took place amid US oil embargo and heightened tensions between two countriesCuban forces killed four exiles and wounded six others who sailed into its waters onboard a Florida-registered speedboat and opened fire on a Cuban patrol, the country’s government said, at a time of heightened tensions with the US.Cuba’s interior ministry said the group comprised anti-government Cubans, some of whom were previously wanted for plotting attacks. They came from the US dressed in camouflage and armed with assault rifles, handguns, homemade explosives, ballistic vests and telescopic sights, it said. Continue reading...
items.content: Rare clash off island’s coast took place amid US oil embargo and heightened tensions between two countriesCuban forces killed four exiles and wounded six others who sailed into its waters onboard a Florida-registered speedboat and opened fire on a Cuban patrol, the country’s government said, at a time of heightened tensions with the US.Cuba’s interior ministry said the group comprised anti-government Cubans, some of whom were previously wanted for plotting attacks. They came from the US dressed in camouflage and armed with assault rifles, handguns, homemade explosives, ballistic vests and telescopic sights, it said. Continue reading...

items.title: Cuba says it killed 4, captured 6 Cuban nationals on U.S. boat planning an 'armed infiltration'
items.standfirst: A U.S. registered speedboat violated Cuban territorial waters, kicking off an armed confrontation with Cuban border guard troops in which four people were killed, Cuban officials said.
items.content: A U.S. registered speedboat violated Cuban territorial waters, kicking off an armed confrontation with Cuban border guard troops in which four people were killed, Cuban officials said.

clusters.title: American jailed over suitcase murder deported from Bali
clusters.neutral_headline: US 'suitcase murderer' deported from Bali after 11 years in jail
bullet_summary: Reported by Sky News World, BBC World, Guardian World

items.title: American jailed over suitcase murder deported from Bali
items.standfirst: Indonesia has freed and deported an American man after he spent 11 years in jail for the premeditated murder of his then-girlfriend's mother, in a case known as the Bali "suitcase murder".
items.content: Indonesia has freed and deported an American man after he spent 11 years in jail for the premeditated murder of his then-girlfriend's mother, in a case known as the Bali "suitcase murder".

items.title: US 'suitcase murderer' deported from Bali after 11 years in jail
items.standfirst: The 33-year-old will still face federal charges in the US and is due to appear in court on Thursday.
items.content: The 33-year-old will still face federal charges in the US and is due to appear in court on Thursday.

items.title: US man deported from Bali after 11 years in prison for ‘suitcase murder’ of then girlfriend’s mother
items.standfirst: Tommy Schaefer released early from sentence for murder of Sheila von Wiese-Mack and will face US federal chargesIndonesia has freed and deported a US man after he spent 11 years in prison for the premeditated murder of his then girlfriend’s mother on the tourist island of Bali, and he will now faces federal charges in the US.Tommy Schaefer was sentenced to 18 years in prison in Bali for the 2014 murder of Sheila von Wiese-Mack, the mother of Heather Mack, during a luxury holiday, in a case that became known as the Bali suitcase murder. Prosecutors allege the couple were trying to gain access to a $1.5m (£1.1m) trust fund. Continue reading...
items.content: Tommy Schaefer released early from sentence for murder of Sheila von Wiese-Mack and will face US federal chargesIndonesia has freed and deported a US man after he spent 11 years in prison for the premeditated murder of his then girlfriend’s mother on the tourist island of Bali, and he will now faces federal charges in the US.Tommy Schaefer was sentenced to 18 years in prison in Bali for the 2014 murder of Sheila von Wiese-Mack, the mother of Heather Mack, during a luxury holiday, in a case that became known as the Bali suitcase murder. Prosecutors allege the couple were trying to gain access to a $1.5m (£1.1m) trust fund. Continue reading...

items.title: Jack Dorsey's Block Plans to Cut Nearly Half of Workforce in AI Bet
items.standfirst: Jack Dorsey's Block aims to improve efficiency by reducing headcount and leveraging artificial intelligence tools. A key focus is on an internal AI tool called Goose, which the company plans to rely on heavily to streamline business processes and enhance productivity. Emily Mason reports on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Jack Dorsey's Block aims to improve efficiency by reducing headcount and leveraging artificial intelligence tools. A key focus is on an internal AI tool called Goose, which the company plans to rely on heavily to streamline business processes and enhance productivity. Emily Mason reports on "Bloomberg The Close." (Source: Bloomberg)

items.title: Jack Dorsey’s Block Slashes Nearly Half Its Staff in AI Bet
items.standfirst: Jack Dorsey’s Block is cutting 4,000 employees, reducing its workforce by nearly half, in a move the financial technology firm is describing as a bet on artificial intelligence changing the future of labor productivity.
items.content: Jack Dorsey’s Block is cutting 4,000 employees, reducing its workforce by nearly half, in a move the financial technology firm is describing as a bet on artificial intelligence changing the future of labor productivity.

clusters.title: World Economic Forum head Børge Brende steps down following pressure over Epstein links
clusters.neutral_headline: Boss of World Economic Forum quits after links to Epstein revealed
bullet_summary: World Economic Forum head Børge Brende said Thursday that he is stepping down after facing pressure over his contacts with the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein
Reported by France24, Guardian Business

items.title: World Economic Forum head Børge Brende steps down following pressure over Epstein links
items.standfirst: World Economic Forum head Børge Brende said Thursday that he is stepping down after facing pressure over his contacts with the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Brende, a former Norwegian foreign minister, said in a statement that he had decided “after careful consideration” to step down as president and chief executive of the forum, known for its annual January summit in the Swiss Alpine resort of Davos. FRANCE 24's Nick Rushworth reports.
items.content: World Economic Forum head Børge Brende said Thursday that he is stepping down after facing pressure over his contacts with the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. Brende, a former Norwegian foreign minister, said in a statement that he had decided “after careful consideration” to step down as president and chief executive of the forum, known for its annual January summit in the Swiss Alpine resort of Davos. FRANCE 24's Nick Rushworth reports.

items.title: Boss of World Economic Forum quits after links to Epstein revealed
items.standfirst: Børge Brende admitted dining with the convicted sex offender on three occasions between 2018 and 2019The boss of the World Economic Forum (WEF) has quit following criticism of his connections to the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein.Børge Brende said he will step down as president and chief executive after more than eight years leading the body, which is best known for its annual meeting held each January in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos. Continue reading...
items.content: Børge Brende admitted dining with the convicted sex offender on three occasions between 2018 and 2019The boss of the World Economic Forum (WEF) has quit following criticism of his connections to the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein.Børge Brende said he will step down as president and chief executive after more than eight years leading the body, which is best known for its annual meeting held each January in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Denmark calls an early election following tense US-Greenland standoff
clusters.neutral_headline: Danish PM calls an early election seeking ‘Greenland bounce’
bullet_summary: Denmark's Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said Thursday that she had scheduled this year's general election for March 24, against a backdrop of tensions with both the United States and Russia
Reported by France24, Guardian World

items.title: Denmark calls an early election following tense US-Greenland standoff
items.standfirst: Denmark's Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said Thursday that she had scheduled this year's general election for March 24, against a backdrop of tensions with both the United States and Russia. The vote comes at a time when Denmark's relationship with the United States -- which Copenhagen considers its closest ally -- has been strained over US President Donald Trump's desire to acquire Greenland. Trine Villeman reports from Copenhagen.
items.content: Denmark's Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen said Thursday that she had scheduled this year's general election for March 24, against a backdrop of tensions with both the United States and Russia. The vote comes at a time when Denmark's relationship with the United States -- which Copenhagen considers its closest ally -- has been strained over US President Donald Trump's desire to acquire Greenland. Trine Villeman reports from Copenhagen.

items.title: Danish PM calls an early election seeking ‘Greenland bounce’
items.standfirst: Mette Frederiksen hopes to profit from her stand against Donald Trump’s attempt to claim the Arctic territoryDenmark’s prime minister has called an early election to take advantage of a “Greenland bounce” after Donald Trump’s threats to invade the Arctic territory.Mette Frederiksen, who has been in office since 2019, is required by Danish law to call an election by 31 October. Setting a date with eight months to go appears to be an attempt to ride improved poll ratings after disastrous local elections in November that saw her Social Democrats lose control of Copenhagen for the first time in a century. Continue reading...
items.content: Mette Frederiksen hopes to profit from her stand against Donald Trump’s attempt to claim the Arctic territoryDenmark’s prime minister has called an early election to take advantage of a “Greenland bounce” after Donald Trump’s threats to invade the Arctic territory.Mette Frederiksen, who has been in office since 2019, is required by Danish law to call an election by 31 October. Setting a date with eight months to go appears to be an attempt to ride improved poll ratings after disastrous local elections in November that saw her Social Democrats lose control of Copenhagen for the first time in a century. Continue reading...
